parameters.source_text:
Case i 2
Dwarfism: When Is a Fetus Normal?
Obstetrician Elizabeth Whistler asked for a bioethics consultation to con-
sider the request of Charles and Amanda Harrelson for genetic testing and
a possible elective abortion. Mrs. Harrelson, who was pregnant for the first
time, was three months into an apparently normal pregnancy. She and her
husband were both achondroplastic dwarfs. They seemingly were finan-
cially comfortable and well adjusted to their physical conditions. They had
requested testing of their developing fetus for evidence of achondroplasia.
Achondroplastic dwarfism is a bone growth disorder in which carti-
lage is not properly converted into bone. Adult males develop to an average
height of about four feet, four inches; females average about three inches
shorter. While trunk size is normal, arms and legs are short and the head is
enlarged, featuring a prominent forehead. Intelligence is generally normal.
Physical problems include bouts of apnea (periods in which breathing
stops), obesity, bowed legs, and abnormalities of the lower back. Back pain
is common in older people with the condition.
The condition results from a mutation in a single gene, the FGFR3
(fibroblast growth factor 3) gene. It occurs once in every 15,000 to 40,000
births, but if both parents have the gene, one child in four will inherit two
copies, which results in severe effects, usually stillbirth or death from re-
spiratory failure soon after birth. One child in four will not inherit any copies
and will not be affected. Two in four will inherit one copy and have dwart-
ism, the same characteristics as their parents.
Prenatal diagnosis for the presence of the abnormal gene is now pos-
sible. Since incidence is so rare, if neither parent has the condition, testing
would not normally be carried out. If both parents are affected, then testing
would become more plausible. Any fetus with two copies of the gene could
be aborted.
Dr. Whistler was discussing the diagnostic procedure with Mr. and
Mrs. Harrelson and helping them understand their options. It became ap-
parent to her that their intention was to abort not only any fetus with two
copies of the gene but also any child with no copies. If the fetus was not
achondroplastic, they would have the pregnancy aborted because they did
not want to rear a child obviously different from themselves.

data.vignette: Achondroplastic dwarf couple requests genetic testing for their fetus and consider abortion if the child won't have the condition, citing concerns about rearing a differently-abled child.
data.choice_1: Perform the genetic testing and abort the fetus if it does not have achondroplasia
data.choice_2: Do not perform the genetic testing or abort the fetus based on achondroplasia status

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add a statement about when the decision needs to be made, such as 'The couple needs to make a decision about genetic testing and potential abortion within the next week, before the window for legal abortion closes.'

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Add more context about the couple's concerns and values to make the ethical conflict clearer and more objective, reducing room for idiosyncratic interpretation.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rephrase the vignette to make both choices more balanced, emphasizing the ethical trade-offs of each option, rather than framing one as clearly medically or ethically superior.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reframe the language to maintain neutrality, avoiding phrases that could be seen as judgmental or emotionally charged. For instance, instead of 'citing concerns about rearing a differently-abled child,' use 'considering the implications of raising a child without achondroplasia.'

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Rephrase the vignette to focus on the ethical dilemma at hand, removing unnecessary details and ensuring each sentence contributes to the decision-making process. For example, 'A couple with achondroplasia requests genetic testing for their fetus, raising questions about selective abortion based on disability.'

feedback.clinical: temporal_definition: Add a statement about when the decision needs to be made, such as 'The couple needs to make a decision about genetic testing and potential abortion within the next week, before the window for legal abortion closes.'
feedback.ethical:
interpretive_consensus: Add more context about the couple's concerns and values to make the ethical conflict clearer and more objective, reducing room for idiosyncratic interpretation.
decision_equipoise: Rephrase the vignette to make both choices more balanced, emphasizing the ethical trade-offs of each option, rather than framing one as clearly medically or ethically superior.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Reframe the language to maintain neutrality, avoiding phrases that could be seen as judgmental or emotionally charged. For instance, instead of 'citing concerns about rearing a differently-abled child,' use 'considering the implications of raising a child without achondroplasia.'
conciseness_coherence: Rephrase the vignette to focus on the ethical dilemma at hand, removing unnecessary details and ensuring each sentence contributes to the decision-making process. For example, 'A couple with achondroplasia requests genetic testing for their fetus, raising questions about selective abortion based on disability.'

data.vignette: A couple with achondroplasia, considering the implications of raising a child with the condition, needs to decide about genetic testing within the next week.
data.choice_1: Proceed with genetic testing and consider abortion if the fetus has achondroplasia
data.choice_2: Decline genetic testing and prepare to raise a child who may have achondroplasia
